lines.text: With or without onions?
With! When your husband's 10,000 miles away, what does it matter?
There's nothing wrong about money that having it can't cure.
[Tony Preston calls late at night]
No, not at all, Mr. Preston. We're here to be disturbed.
Careful, Mrs. Preston. I wouldn't want you to get hurt. Not yet.
Come on, darling, fair exchange. One fib for a broken date.
Practical jokers have particular talents. Not commendable, but highly special.
Nora won the Irish Sweep, madam, and left. I'm the new maid.
If he cares enough, he'll find me.
Take Bea. She's a gay soul. At least you'll have a chuckle or two.
That's the way I've always dreamed of going to Venice. The moon on the Grand Canal, and the gondolier singing, and Aunt Bea beside me... chuckling.
You wouldn't want an irresponsible husband.
No, darling. Just a husband.
Don't ever change.
I try not to, but the bills at the beauty parlor get bigger every year.

[telegram]
Weather beastly and so is my host.
At least your husband comes home at night. All I have of Roy is a signature at the bottom of a weekly letter. Try cuddling up with THAT.
Sometimes I think the Blitz left us with more derelict minds than derelict buildings.
How's Bea? Did she bring any stuffed heads back with her?
One. She met him on the plane.
Thank heavens there are no tigers in London.
Ah, the jungle of finance. Men must work, and women must weep!

I was once in Dublin for the horse show, and I got a call at the Sheldon Room from a man who wanted to dress me in black underwear. Personally, mind you! It was the most *stimulating* minute-and-a-half I spent in Ireland!
We all meet death somewhere along the way.

[opening door]
Oh, it's you, Bea.
It usually is when I've been invited.
[debating whether to call the police late at night]
Anyway, we'd better let the Inspector know. No reason why he shouldn't have insomnia with the rest of us.
Before the war I planned on being an architect. But that meant an office and four walls. I even sleep out under the stars whenever I can. Camping trips and things like that.
That's fine if you're married to a Girl Scout.
'Swan Lake' makes me terribly thirsty.
Must have something to do with those long necks.
Now, Mrs. Covent. Do you recollect exactly what your niece said to you on the phone?
Yes. She said, "Aunt Bea, help me, help me."
And what did you assume she meant, Mrs. Covent?
That she needed help, Inspector!
Doesn't he think it's dangerous leaving an attractive girl alone for months on end?

[speaking to Tony about Kit]
She's being tormented by a sadistic fiend!
Get her, Tony, get her!
